COMMENT:  The following article illuminated 2 things to me:  why anyone cares about Montenegro, and it describes Putin/Russia's claimed involvement in a recent  attempt to pull off a pro-Russian coup.  If Montenegro was to have a pro-Russian government, the prospects of ratification of  NATO membership would slip to zero for the duration of it. http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/26/world/europe/finger-pointed-at-russians-in-alleged-coup-plot-in-montenegro.html?emc=edit_th_20161127&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=77825025 "With a few thousand soldiers, a handful of tanks and only 600,000 residents, Montenegro — whose application to join NATO was accepted in May and now awaits ratification — is hardly a military powerhouse. But it controls the only stretch of coastline where warships can dock between Gibraltar and eastern Turkey not already in the hands of the alliance. “There is a big struggle going on,” . . .  “We are the last piece of the Mediterranean that is not already in NATO, the last piece in a big puzzle.” . . . "Kotor Bay [is} a deepwater haven long coveted by both Russia and the West for its strategic location. "In early October, Father Krivokapic presided over a ceremony in Kotor for the foundation of the Balkan Cossack Army, a Russian-led grouping of Pan-Slavic nationalists bitterly hostile to NATO. The priest described the gathering as “just folklore,” featuring men in fur hats and imperial-era costumes. Yet it was also attended by members of the Night Wolves, a Russian motorcycle gang whose leader is a friend of Mr. Putin’s, and mercenaries who have fought in eastern Ukraine on the side of Russian-backed separatists. "The anti-NATO clamor has succeeded in weakening already lukewarm public support for the alliance, which even some pro-Western voices view as a needless provocation of Russia and a ploy by Milo Djukanovic, Montenegro’s longtime and notoriously devious leader, to cement his power with help from the United States. So when Mr. Djukanovic announced that his government was the target of a Russian-backed plot in October, opposition politicians — both pro- and anti-NATO — as well as much of the news media and many independent observers dismissed the claim as a fairy tale. Since then, however, Mr. Sindjelic, has begun talking. He was held for three weeks . . .  and then released this past week as a “protected witness.” . He has told investigators about his visit to Moscow, about sophisticated encrypted telephones and about the more than $200,000 he says he was given as a down payment for his role as a recruiter of muscle for the operation, people close to the investigation said. Also talking is another central figure in the alleged plot, a former Serbian gendarmerie commander named Bratislav Dikic. He initially denied any involvement after his arrest on Oct. 16 shortly before polling began in an election that the pro-Russian opposition politicians had hoped to win. The results were inconclusive.
. . . .
". . . the Montenegrin prosecutor handling the coup case, told reporters in early November that there was no solid proof yet that the Russian state had been involved. He blamed “Russian nationalists” who wanted “to stop Montenegro on its Euro-Atlantic path, especially to prevent its accession to NATO.” . . .
The official version of what happened in October still contains many holes, including the failure by the authorities in Montenegro to produce any of the weapons they say were to be used in an Election Day attack on Parliament in Podgorica by conspirators disguised as police officers.
. . . 
"Serbia’s prime minister, Aleksandar Vucic, who has struggled to balance strong pro-Russian sentiment in his country with his own policy of shifting cautiously toward the West, was outraged to hear that Russian citizens and Serbian nationalists had been working together under his nose in Belgrade to stage a coup in Montenegro. He swiftly announced a shake-up of Serbia’s intelligence services, many of whose members have traditionally leaned toward Russia and view the West as an enemy, a feeling that intensified with NATO’s 1999 bombing campaign. "There has also been a small shake-up in Moscow with Mr. Putin’s abrupt and unexplained dismissal of Leonid Reshetnikov, a former Soviet intelligence officer, as head of the Russian Institute for Strategic Studies, a research group that works for the Kremlin. The institute had been in the forefront of Russian efforts to derail Montenegro’s NATO membership and has extensive links to pro-Russian groups in the Balkans. "After initially dismissing Montenegro’s claim of a coup plot, Mr. Vucic, Serbia’s prime minister, announced that there was “incontrovertible evidence” that “certain people” had placed Mr. Djukanovic, Montenegro’s leader, under close surveillance using “the most modern equipment” and were reporting to co-conspirators who “were supposed to act in accordance with their instructions.”  Several people “who were acting in coordination with foreigners” had been arrested in Serbia, he said. Among those arrested was Mr. Sindjelic . . . "Adding to a fog of fearful foreboding, the Serbian authorities then announced they had uncovered a cache of arms near Mr. Vucic’s family home in Belgrade, a stash that Serbian news media outlets said had been put there in preparation for an assassination attempt against the Serbian leader, too.  Mr. Sindjelic has told investigators that he is uncertain about the exact affiliations of Mr. Popov and Mr. Shirikov. He said only that when he visited Moscow in September to discuss the Montenegro plot, he was hosted in a luxury apartment and was warned that he was dealing with dangerous people and should take care not to step out of line. "But there are now so many Russians who have a stake in Montenegro’s future — including tens of thousands who vacation each year on its glorious coast, anti-Kremlin figures who have sought refuge in its proximity to the West, shady investors looking for a place to stash their money, and a murky cast of intelligence operatives and nationalists who want to keep NATO out — the country, too, has to tread carefully. "Montenegro", said  . . .a former deputy mayor of . . . a coastal town that is particularly popular with Russians, “is the new Casablanca.”

https://sputniknews.com/politics/201610171046397341-montenegro-nato-elections/ ". . . within just several months we will ratify a protocol on Montenegro’s joining NATO and decide on the Montenegro’s NATO membership,” Dukanovic told his supporters late [last] Sunday.

COMMENT:  The recent parliamentary election in Montenegro resulted in no party getting a majority of the 81 seats.  This is important because the parliament  will have to vote to either (1) authorize a referendum on NATO membership or (2) ratify/ accept NATO membership on its own.    So, the questions are:
-will the public peacefully accept the election results?  There's a fear that Putin may fund protests.  Ironically, this might have the effect of strengthening the government in power.
-will DPS (with 36 out of 81 seats) form a coalition government and Dukanovic return as PM?  This most likely would result in a vote by parliament to accept the invitation to join NATO, or
-will the opposition parties form a coalition government?  This most likely would result in a vote to hold a referendum on NATO accession, which may/may not garner public support And finally,  can all of this, as well as ratification by about 20 more countries, happen in the next approx 2 months. I say "No." ~~~~~~~~~
http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2016/10/16/montenegro-elections-beyond-nato-russia-dichotomy/ "Some of the opposition parties demand that the decision on membership be taken directly by the citizens via a referendum, while a vote in the parliament is the route NATO expects from Montenegro. For the Alliance, a referendum is the least desirable option, and the reasons are clear: public support for membership is not very high, and the risks of a ‘no’ vote would be considerable.  . . .  "For NATO, the refusal of the invitation to join the alliance would set a decidedly unfavourable precedent.  . . . because of the fact that Russia is openly opposed to Montenegro’s NATO accession, and a Montenegrin ‘no’ vote would be a victory for Russia in what is now popularly referred to as ‘hybrid warfare’.  . . .  "The much toughened fight against corruption and organised crime which has been playing out over the past 20 months is mostly an effect of EU and NATO conditionality and of the distancing from the Russian ‘business model’. But this fight is also closely linked to the economic situation. Stopping the abuse of public office, the undue seizure of state property and the large-scale tax dodging would greatly improve the stability and the sustainability of Montenegro’s budget. . . .  "Montenegro’s most transparent election yet.  This election is held in conditions which are previously unseen in Montenegro. 
. . . 
"Looked at from the outside, the 2016 parliamentary elections are thus being held with the most regular and transparent conditions so far. The leading party DPS has never been exposed to so many detailed checks. This does not mean, however, that the control of the opposition parties within the government has been flawless and entirely successful. It only stands as a reminder of how complex and problematic the electoral cycles are in Montenegro, . . .  "According to estimates based on publicly available information, the political parties have spent more than ever on this election. . . . The question of where the DF get their money from has been much debated, but the answer to it is not known yet. The DPS accuse them of being financed by the Russian tycoons close to Vladimir Putin, with the aim of stopping Montenegro’s accession to NATO.  . . . DPS’ campaign funding has also remained leargely unclear so far. It is emblematic of the wider picture that the funding of Montenegro’s two most influential parties is a mystery. ". . .  the DPS has decided . . .  to let their leader, Milo Đukanović, be the mouthpiece of the whole campaign . . . who remains the most influential and the most powerful figure in the country.  In his appearances, Đukanović sent a message characterising these elections as a test for the independence of Montenegro, for the safeguarding of its identity and sovereignty, which is the same topic that was debated at the referendum held ten years ago.
. . . 
"Regardless of the result of the elections, it is not realistic to expect that a government will be formed soon. If the DPS do not manage to gather enough votes to form a comfortable majority with the parties representing the ethnic minorities (Bosniaks, Albanians and Croats), who are DPS’ usual allies, the formation of the government could become very complex. "One possible outcome is that the ‘pro-Western’ forces might agree to form a government which wlll finalise the NATO accession process and continue on the EU integration path. This government would be very similar to the ‘Government of electoral trust’ which was in power before the elections.  As things stand, the biggest obstacle to the realisation of this scenario is the agreement which was signed by the opposition parties – which have committed themselves not to agree, under any circumstances, to forming a government with the DPS. On the other hand, another obstacle for government formation without the DPS is that some opposition parties have incompatible stances on foreign policy issues, such as NATO, the recognition of Kosovo and the sanctions against Russia. The hardest line is represented by the DF, which is at the same time the strongest opposition party, likely to scoop a considerable share of the vote. It is yet unclear how a compromise on these issues could be found between the DF and pro-Western parties such as SDP and the movement URA. "Although the incoherence of the opposition’s stances on foreign policy plays in the DPS’ favour, their position is not much easier. . . . the possible opposition partners would be able to claw back a good amount of power from the party that has been continuously ruling over Montenegro from the end of the second world war . . . .
. . . 
"The country’s economic situation is very worrying: strikes by unhappy citizens or workers of failed state enterprises are an everyday occurrance. Autumn 2015 was marked by anti-government protests which ended in street unrests – a reminder that a slender majority would not be able to guarantee stability to Montenegro. "A further challenge will be maintaining peace and order in the country after the announcement of the results. . . .  it cannot be excluded that certain political forces might declare the elections ‘stolen’ and call citizens onto the streets. Montenegro does not have a track record of protests ending peacefully, nor has it so far ever been possible to actually protect the ‘electoral will’ in this way. Quite on the contrary, such demonstrations have usually ended up with the strengthening of the government in power, seen as a stronghold against the ‘destructive opposition’.

The election campaign is deeply divided among those who favor and those who oppose European and Euro-Atlantic integration. On the second day of the NATO Summit in Warsaw in July, the Alliance adopted the Political Declaration welcoming Montenegro as a new member of the Alliance. What remains is the ratification of the Protocol on the Accession. That could take place via a referendum or the next parliament. Prime Minister Djukanovic has made clear he prefers the latter. If the current government were to lose these coming elections, Montenegro could reject NATO membership."

http://www.foreign.senate.gov/hearings/nato-expansion-examining-the-accession-of-montenegro_091416p Update: video of hearing available. Any GJP forecaster that has diligently followed the topic of the accession of Montenegro to NATO over the past year or so will likely come away with the feeling that they know more about the issue than the two senior Senators of this committee, that U.S. foreign policy is so ridiculous that it would assume a defensive commitment in such a nonchalant fashion, and with the impression that it's a "done deal." As to timing, the pathetic Senate, as with the rest of the world generally, is being hustled along so as to "move forward as expeditiously as possible." [I lost some regard for Senator Johnson here. First, he uses the instance of 9-11 as an example of alliance solidarity. Then, he casually discounts the risk of guaranteeing the defense of Montenegro by citing the fact that it is 800 or so miles from the closest Russian border. Setting aside the obvious near-sightedness of presuming Russia to be the only possible relevant adversary, the very example of alliance unity he cites is one where border distance was not relevant. That's sloppy thinking. I also lost regard for the entire U.S. Senate here as well. What could be more important to ninety-five or so other senators than the heaping on of additional political and military risk to this country over the foreseeable future? I pray that this event is not one that some future historian, in seeking to reconstruct the progression of some future conflict, looks upon with aghast disbelief -- as I am so doing today.]

Montenegro is in the process of joining NATO. In December 2015, the Allies have invited the country to begin accession talks which then took place in early 2016. On 19 May 2016, Allied foreign ministers signed the Accession Protocol for Montenegro. Following the signature of the Protocol, Montenegro has ‘Invitee’ status, allowing its representatives to participate as observers in Allied meetings. Once all 28 Allies have ratified the Accession Protocol, Montenegro can then accede to the Washington Treaty and become a full member of the Alliance

"The Pentagon said it was grateful to Montenegro"
http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/alleged-bin-laden-bodyguard-transferred-gitmo-montenegro-n597486 I think of Montenegro as a kind-of "pocket-country," similar to the idea of a "pocket battleship" from the between world wars period of Europe: built to conform with technical treaty limitations, but in reality something far different than what most people had expected to result. In short, it is unhelpful to carry over all the typical connotations we associate with the word "country" whenever speaking of Montenegro. "the Euro-Atlantic democratic community" 
http://warontherocks.com/2016/06/natos-open-door-leads-to-an-identity-crisis/ The Brexit debate, for me anyway, has made it abundantly clear that "democracy" is something that comes in degrees. Just to call something "democratic" does not make it so. So, for example, from my perspective, whatever good the EU has, it is fatally flawed because it is anti-democratic. Yet, some people still call it democratic. Perhaps we need to establish some minimum level of democracy before we allow such terms to be applied as labels to organizations or governments. Moreover, from Dilma in Brazil, the Panama Papers, and my dear friend @ravel's consistent reminders, I've learned that any degree of democracy is no democracy at all if it is subverted by corruption. In that sense, "corruption-free" is a necessary condition for any degree of democracy to obtain. And, the greater the degree of democracy an organization looks like it has from its formal structure, the greater the amount of democracy that is lost when it is not corruption-free. So, at least for myself, I'm beginning to get really picky in allowing myself to assent to designations of "democracy" based on mere labeling alone.

Every NATO Ally must then ratify the Protocol in their national parliaments in order for it to become a full member"[1]. At least this confirms my understanding of the matter. A little more interesting is this: "Montenegro has agreed a new contract with the Washington-based firm Orion Strategies to advocate for the country's accession bid, according to a US Department of Justice filing. The firm will provide strategic communications, PR and advocacy around issues and news relating to Montenegro in the US and Europe and around the country's bid for membership of the Western military alliance. Orion Strategies will receive $150,000 for services delivered over a 12-month period ending on February 1, 2017"[2].  ***Update: I had the wrong Orion Strategies. The one in Washington, DC is quite small, no more than 4 employees. So I guess the same questions apply, for whatever they're worth: http://www.manta.com/c/mm7skmv/orion-strategies A few thoughts about this latter nugget: First, I wouldn't want to make too much of the 2017 termination date. It's probably just a result of when the contract was signed. Second, $150K doesn't seem like much. How much value are they going to get for that kind of money. This would get you two experienced IT guys, if you're lucky. That's all you're going to spend on lobbying the US gov't? Perhaps Montenegro's gov't doesn't think much work needs to be done. Third, who the hell are these Orion guys? Though the article refers to Orion as "Washington-based," it looks like it's actually located in West Virginia[3]. I've sent them an email asking for clarification. It's not a big deal, but why would you wire a WV firm to lobby in DC? Honestly, Orion seems a little bush league. Again, I'm not sure whether Montenegro's gov't thinks that this one is in the bag or whether they've just made some bad choices, and their accession protocol is going to receive ratification more slowly than it otherwise might have. COMMENT:  I find it interesting that this online vote was set up as between NATO membership and "neutrality"; "neutrality"  really is code for pro-Russia. Montenegro is a young nation without much historical or cultural cohesion.  Like Ukraine, half the country is Byzantine Catholic and pro-Europe/west-leaning, while the other half is Russian Orthodox and pro-Russia/east-leaning.  This division is far, far older than the country and won't be healed anytime soon.  However, nevertheless, it sounds like improving public support for NATO membership is one of the items on Montenegro's "to do" list for NATO membership:  something I consider an impossible task, which, I'm assuming NATO officials/members will just brush under the rug in the end. My low forecast on this question is because of the complexity of getting all 28 member states to ratify/approve Montenegro's membership.

Also, I checked some info about FYR Macedonia. Their membership plan was issued on 1999, but nothing has been done so far. For Montenegro, their plan was issued in 2009. This doesn't mean much (especially since most other countries took much less time to enter). I normally wouldn't change my forecast for this, but I also have to factor in that we are in mid-April. COMMENT:  Consider the source (Russian), but also consider that this represents the opinion of at least 1/3rd of Montenegrans.

Does this matter? "A number of political and public figures of Montenegro signed a declaration against integration of the country into NATO. They are Metropolitan Amfilohie, Bishop Ioanichie and professor Nikola Kusovac and others. The document strongly criticizes Milo Djukanovic's decision to join NATO"[a]. Probably not. It can't be a surprise that at least some "political and public figures of Montenegro" are not in favor of joining NATO. Is there any major U.S. policy that isn't strongly resisted by at least some political and public figures here? Ah, the course of true NATO membership never did run smooth. Moreover, Russian sources (like this one) tend to skew anti-NATO, so whatever value this news item should be discounted.  More important, perhaps, is the continued silence about Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic's comments on joining NATO is mid-2017[b]. Maybe Djukanovic is trying to calm down the Russians, though I'm not sure this would do the trick. Maybe Djukanovic is trying to give his domestic opponents the sense that there is more time on the shot clock than there actually is. Or maybe Djukanovic just foresees Montenegro joining NATO in mid-2017.  @Counterintelligence is quite right to point out that there has been a recent history of completing the process of joining NATO in less than a year. Sure, the sample size is small, but I take it that what's salient here is the fact that it *can* be done in less than 13 months. Montenegro is a tiny, itty-bitty speck of a nation-state. (The population of Montenegro is roughly equal to the population of Memphis, TN.) Off-hand, that suggests that questions of military and political integration might be far easier to resolve than in the case of larger nation-states like Albania (whose population is roughly equal to that of Chicago, IL - so, still pretty damn tiny).  Corruption levels are crazy high in Montenegro[c][d]. But not as high as in Albania[e], and Croatia's not that much better[f], if we want to focus on a couple of recent NATO joiners. Come to think of it, corruption levels in Montenegro are about the same as those in Italy[g]! So I don't see any special reason that corruption is likely to gum up the works.  And what's all this about Russia then[h]? I suspect - without the slightest bit of actual evidence, mind you - that Russia is pressing NATO leadership for some quid pro quo. Russia can't, of course, veto Montenegro membership, but it can create a lot of headaches that NATO leadership doesn't want to deal with. Negotiations with Putin might slow down Montenegro's membership, but we're unlikely to be privy to any of that (unless we're fluent in neo-kremlinology[i], and I'm not). So I'm sitting tight for now and waiting to see what comes next. -- [a] http://peacekeeper.ru/en/?module=news&action=view&id=29155

REASONS WHY THIS MAY NOT OCCUR IN 2016
-Montenegro is not politically stable.   
    Djukanovick survived a vote of confidence,  but had to rely on the votes of an opposition party after his own coalition partner abandoned him.
-Montenegro is economically weak
-Montenegro is socially divided 
-the shadow economy represents about 50% of GDP (a)

If I'd been asked before December 2015 how likely it was that Montenegro would have been offered an invitation to join NATO, I would have been a little pessimistic. After all, there have been no new NATO members since 2009 (Albania and Croatia), and there has been no single nation entries since 1984 (Spain). But here we are. Montenegro applied for NATO membership in 2003 and has been moving forward with this process (more or less) steadily since then[1]. NATO issued a formal invitation to Montenegro in December of 2015, beginning the final accession talks which could be concluded at the summit in Warsaw during July of 2016[2]. Clearly, things have changed a lot since NATO bombed Montenegro 17 years ago as part of Kosovo War[3]. So - given what we now know - how likely is it that Montenegro will join in the remainder of 2016? As far as I can tell, no country that has been formally offered NATO membership has rejected it, though, of course, France left NATO in 1966, only to return later[4]. Still, I'd hesitate to assign an initial probability of 1.0 to Montenegro's accepting NATO's invitation. Instead, call it 0.98. The process of moving from invitation to acceptance usually takes 12-18 months[5]. I suspect that the best way to read that fact is that the odds of acceptance during the first 6 months are pretty low, the odds go way up for the next 2 sets of 6 months, and then get a bit lower during the following set of 6 months. That looks something like this: Jan-June 2016: 0.04 (just too quick, I think)
July-Dec 2016: 0.41
Jan-June 2017: 0.41
July-Dec 2017: 0.12
Black Swan: 0.02  So I think the baseline is a 0.45 probability that Montenegro will join in 2016. But there are some reasons for thinking that the smart prediction should be lower, and there are some reasons for thinking it should be higher. I'll go through each set. Let's start with reasons for thinking that the smart prediction should be lower. Russia is not happy about Montenegro joining NATO[6]. Of course, Russia doesn't have a formal veto. Now, Russia might use military force to try to scare Montenegro into backing away from NATO, but any attempt to do so is likely to cause Montenegro to want NATO's protection even more. And Russia might try to use more subtle pressure (economic boycotts, cyber espionage, perhaps even targeted assassinations), yet Mr. Putin hasn't shown it can do subtle terribly well, so I remain doubtful. The Democratic Party of Socialists of Montenegro and the Social Democratic Party of Montenegro want Montenegro to become NATO member state, but the Socialist People's Party of Montenegro is less enthusiastic. The polls have been all over the place and seem to me to be less than predictive. At any rate, I don't think the ruling parties need a plebiscite in order to continue with NATO membership, so unless the country becomes unstable because of street-level opposition, I don't think that this will slow down the process. To sum up: External Causes (i.e., Russia) = -0.08
Internal Causes (i.e., Montenegrin opposition) = -0.01

That gives us the following results: Jan-June 2016: 0.036
July-Dec 2016: 0.373
Jan-June 2017: 0.373
July-Dec 2017: 0.109
Black Swan or Offer Rejected for External or Internal Causes: 0.11 Hence, the first adjustment to the baseline =.4095.  Now let's turn to the reasons for thinking that the smart prediction should be higher. It's worth noting that Prime Minister Milo Djukanovic survived a no-confidence vote on January 27, so he's likely to feel like he has something of a mandate to implement his agenda right now[7], before the elections in late 2016. Moreover, NATO is holding a summit meeting in Poland this summer[8]. NATO summit meetings generally happen every other year (though there are certainly exceptions)[9]. In 2009, Albania and Croatia joined NATO just 2 days before the meeting[10], so it looks like the 2016 date of the summit meeting predicts Montenegro's joining this year. However, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Slovakia, Bulgaria and Romania joined a good 4 months before the 2004 NATO summit meeting[11]. Hence, the connection seems a little tenuous. Given the upheavals that Europe has been growing through of late, it wouldn't be much of a surprise if there was a 2017 NATO summit meeting as well.  Survival of no-confidence vote: +0.05
2016 date of NATO summit meeting: +0.01 Thus, the smart prediction =0.4695 (which we can call 0.47).  But here's another data point to throw a spanner in the works: "Montenegro's ambassador to Italy, Antun Sbutega, said at an event held by Istituto Affari Internazionali on Wednesday that the country would become a NATO member in 2017 ''barring unforeseen circumstances''."[12] Whoa, if true. I can't find any confirmation of this in any language I speak, but it only happened on Tuesday, so let's just see what happens. If there's any confirmation, then I'll adjust my forecast. If there's no confirmation, I'll carry on like I didn't see anything. -- [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accession_of_Montenegro_to_NATO [2] http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_125370.htm [3] http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/11/AR2009031100547.html [4] http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/longterm/balkans/stories/montenegro050399.htm [5] http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/01/nato-to-ask-montenegro-to-join-alliance [6] https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/yugoslavia-montenegro/2015-12-24/new-thorn-russias-side [7] http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-27/montenegro-pm-wins-vote-of-confidence-after-offering-concessions [8] http://www.mfa.gov.pl/en/news/first_meeting_of_inter_ministerial_group_for_preparing_nato_summit_in_warsaw [9] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO_summit [10] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Strasbourg%E2%80%93Kehl_summit [11] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Istanbul_summit [12] http://www.ansamed.info/ansamed/en/news/sections/politics/2016/02/17/montenegro-to-join-nato-in-2017_eee4d6f9-19c8-46a9-8c22-1d9a6d155ef2.html

On one hand, NATO has not accepted a new member in seven years (2009). On the other hand, Montenegro is the only one of four countries with a MAP that does not face internal NATO objections like, say, Greece to Macedonia. The last two countries to enter NATO (Albania and Croatia) did so about one year after the official invitation, even with some objections in 2008-2009 from Slovenia to Croatian membership. Therefore, I think the consensus of 33 percent is low. NATO is holding its Warsaw Summit in July, which should provide further impetus for NATO and Montenegro to get this done within the year. Russia has little economic influence over Montenegro, thus diminishing intimidation from Moscow as a depressing factor. And although NATO membership is supported by less than half of Montenegro (although that is divided largely along ethnic lines), the PM just survived a no-confidence vote, so he probably has enough domestic political support to finalize NATO membership sometime in 2016 (particularly since he appears to have survived the vote by generally committing to reforms that NATO coincidentally supports -- at least rhetorically. Moreover, Montenegro represents relative low-hanging fruit (compared to Georgia, Macedonia, and others) for NATO to demonstrate that it remains a confident organization in the wake of its perceived acquiescence to Russian aggression in Ukraine. And although Montenegro wouldn't be a game changer, it does represent a somewhat militarily significant move for NATO (a military alliance after all) in that it forestalls any concern about Russian air defense and missiles making their way into the Adriatic (like Moscow is positioned in the Baltics).

In the previous three post-Cold War expansions, two had more-than-a-year periods between invitation and accession (July '97-March '99, Nov '02-March '04) while one had a barely-short-of-a-year (April '08-April '09).  Further, a major driver of the timing of completion of accessions in all three cases seems to have been beating NATO summit dates.  But to beat the 2016 summit, Montenegro's accession would have to be done by 8 July, for the shortest invitation-to-accession ever.   It seems possible but not particularly likely that Montenegro's accession will be seen as important enough to force it through before the 27th NATO Summit this year, and if it isn't so accelerated, it will likely be allowed to languish on everybody's legislative calendars into 2017.

No change. Alright -- there's been some discussion as to whether this will resolve on the ascension talks or the ratification -- as an FYI, I submitted a clarification request. I suspect that GJ won't offer any advice and here's why... I checked into the two most recent additions of NATO memberships (i.e. base rates?) and it looks like both were classified as members AFTER the ratification. Albania --> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albania%E2%80%93NATO_relations#Negotiation_progress
Croatia --> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatia%E2%80%93NATO_relations#Negotiation_progress Both were invited to join (April 3rd, 2008) and completed ascension protocol (July 9th, 2008) at the same time. From that data, we can probably assume that, barring anything drastic, Montenegro will probably also complete their ascension protocol before the meeting this summer (July). That means they have about 5+ months to have things ratified by all the countries who are already members (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accession_of_Montenegro_to_NATO#Negotiation_progress). So, let's look and see how long it took the OTHER two countries to have things ratified. It's worth noting that BOTH of those countries had their ascension protocol completed on July 9th and that will be right around the same time that Montenegro will be having their ascension protocol completed (assuming they get things done by the summer). ***drumroll please*** Croatia and Albania didn't become full members until........ April 1st of the next year. Translation: three months too late by our deadline! If someone wants they could probably go through and look and see if there were any issues with any of the countries at the time (i.e. reasons why legislation may have been held up? From my quick scan, it looks like all countries ratifying did so for both Albania/Croatia on the same day. I did a quick count of the number of countries that ratified after Dec 31st (because that's what we're interested in, right?) By my count -- 9 out of 26 countries ratified after Dec 31. Not only would Montenegro need to have those 9 countries on the right side of Dec 31st, they'd have to have two MORE countries (Albania/Croatia) on the right side of Dec 31 -- and that assumes that some of those countries that ratified on the right side of Dec 31st wouldn't slip into the following year. It's worth noting, for those of you who think that the US might hold things up, I suspect not (?) because the US ratified Croatia/Albania on... September 26th, 2008. Not only was it an election year, there were other major events happening in the US at the time. For those interested, here's a list of those who ratified after Dec 31st for Albania/Croatia:
*Belgium (Jan 29)
*Canada (Jan 14)
*France (Feb 4)
*Greece (Feb 17)
*Iceland (Feb 12)
*Luxembourg (Feb 12)
*Netherlands (Feb 17)
*Portugal (Feb 13)
*Slovenia (Feb 9) And here's seven countries that ratified in December:
*Czech Republic (Dec 22)
*Denmark (Dec 9)
*Estonia (Dec 19)
*Germany (Dec 19)
*Italy (Dec 23)
*Spain (Dec 18)
*UK (Dec 19) And two more in late November:
*Norway (Nov 24)
*Turkey (Nov 26) All that to say... I'm staying very low on this IFP -- at least -- until it's clear that Montenegro will pass the first hurdle (ascension protocol).

Somehow at first glance I would completely disregard this question, NATO would not in their right mind pursue an expansion whilst the conflict in the Ukraine and bombing operations in Syria from the Russians are not resolved. There is considerable risk and repercussions. But, let us approach it differently… The question is more about Balkan expansion, both for the EU and Nato. Let us look to Croatia for guidance. 1.       Croatia became a Nato member in 2009, EU member in 2013 and will get the Euro in 2019. It has a GDP of 11,5 k$/p 2.       How did it happen? Croatia got Memberip Action Plan (MAP) in 2002 (for the Nato). It started the SAA (economical/political reforms for the EU) in 2000 and were inforce by 2005. There are a number of intersecting issues to balance when looking this particular question: 1. The time between invitation and actual accession to NATO is often more than a year among former Soviet bloc nation.
2. Montenegro's leadership is undergoing its first real test. Demonstrations occurred in December (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-montenegro-protests-idUSKCN0SC0SR20151018) and one of the leading coalition's member groups just left. This instability is likely to delay membership, especially if a referendum is held this year.
3. Montenegro's leadership has been very interested in joining the European Union, and NATO membership has often been a gateway for discussions.
4. Russia has signaled its displeasure with continued NATO expansion. If this was a nation like Slovenia, this would bare little impact. However, Russia has historically had close cultural ties with the Yugoslavian area, and they may be able to apply some indirect influence to delay or stop further action to join NATO.

In isolation it looks extremely likely that Montenegro will become a member in 2016. Montenegro has consistently stated its desire to join and has been part of the accession process since 2006. They have provided troops for NATO operations and have the support of a number of key members. They have been invited to join and are currently at the final accession stage that requires ratification from all other member states. New NATO members tend to be accepted into the organisation at summits. The next summit is in July 2016 in Warsaw and comments from NATO and Montenegro have pointed to this event as the target for full membership.  We don't live in isolation though and there are a number of external factors that should be taken into account. Current relations between Russia and NATO are poor. One reason for this is the topic of Ukraine and Georgia possibly becoming NATO members in the future. Any expansion of NATO in this environment is likely to shine a light on Ukraine and Georgia membership again which will antagonize the Russian leadership. Russia has gone as far as saying that joining NATO makes Montenegro a target for Russian missiles. This has led some NATO members to question the timing of Montenegro's accession with France being one of the more vocal opponents. There is also opposition to membership at home that stems partly from the 1999 bombing of Montenegro by NATO forces. Protests have increased in recent months. Despite these complications I still believe that full membership will be awarded to Montenegro around the date of the Warsaw summit. Russia was posturing before Montenegro was officially invited to join in December 2015. While Russia may shout even louder once they do become members it is more to do with Ukraine and Georgia than  A small nation with three other countries between Russia and themselves. Montenegro does have important port access to the Aegean but access to this is not a realistic possibility for Russia.  Domestic opposition is similar to what was seen in Croatia and Albania prior to their accession and is unlikely to change the current momentum towards full membership. One possible delaying factor is the necessary approval from all other members. France has voiced concerns about the timing of accession and full membership requires unanimous approval. It remains to be seen how strongly France feels about holding Montenegro back for a period of time. In the wake of attacks in Paris, one could argue that a new member of NATO in the Balkans will help protect Europe from terrorist attacks but that seems to be a fairly weak assumption. Perhaps with the ratification by the likes of Germany and the US, France's opposition will fall away. The risk of a member country not ratifying is currently the largest threat to full membership. If there were significant concerns I would imagine the invitation to join would not have been given in December 2015. I also believe that NATO will want to avoid any embarrassing disagreements among member states in the current environment. Therefore, combined with some risk that Montenegro gets cold feet due to saber rattling by Russia, I think the chances of them not joining in 2016 are low and in the region of 13%. This risk will increase if we fail to see the ratification process begin around May 2016 in time for a formal announcement in July.

Vote of No Confidence – Procedural Information Filing the Request:  Two ways exist to introduce a vote of no confidence.  The first is for the Prime Minister to file the request with Parliament in writing on behalf of the Government. The Government includes the Prime Minister, Deputy Prime Minister(s), and Ministers. The second way to introduce the request is for 27 members of Parliament to file.   The Prime Minister has announced the Government shall submit a request to Parliament for a vote of confidence within 15 days of December 28.  http://www.gov.me/en/News/156481/Government-announces-candidancy-of-FM-Luksic-for-UN-Secretary-General-to-submit-request-for.html Parliamentary Debate:  Because the Prime Minister made the request, he may explain it to Parliament. The vote is subject to debate. Each MP may speak up to 10 minutes. After completion of the debate, voting commences. Vote:  Parliament both elects and dismisses the Prime Minister and the Government by a majority vote. The vote is open.  Each MP must state either “for confidence” or “against confidence.” Consequences:  When the Government loses confidence, its mandate ceases.  The government continues until the election is held for a new government.  A government that loses confidence is not allowed to dissolve Parliament. Not directly related to the Vote of No Confidence but interesting to know:  A referendum proposal may be submitted to Parliament by petition of 25 MPs, the President, the Government, or minimum 10% of citizens who have the right to vote.  Parliament “calls for” the referendum by majority vote. Information from:
Parliament Rules of Procedure:  http://www.skupstina.me/images/documents/rules_of_procedure_00-63-2.pdf
Constitution of Montenegro:  http://www.skupstina.me/index.php/en/ustav-crne-gore

Montenegro completed its first MAP cycle in 2010.  This process allowed the country to identify key challenges that needed to be addressed, including reinforcing the rule of law, meeting NATO standards in security sector reforms and fighting corruption and organised crime.  In December 2015 to invite the country to being accession talks to join the Alliance. They stated that they expect further progress on reforms, especially in the area of rule of law and that NATO will continue to provide support and assistance though the MAP. During the period leading up to accession, NATO will involve Montenegro in Alliance activities to the greatest extent possible, including the Warsaw Summit in July 2016. In February 2010, Montenegro decided to contribute troops to the NATO-led International Assistance Force (ISAF) in Afghanistan, which were deployed there together with a Croatian unit. Following the completion of ISAF’s operation at the end of 2014, Montenegro is currently supporting the follow-on mission (‘Resolute Support’) to train, advise and assist the Afghan security forces. In support of past efforts to equip and train the Afghan National Army, Montenegro donated more than 1,600 weapons and 250,000 rounds of ammunition. The government has also pledged financial support for the future development of the Afghan National Security Forces.  The net contribution of any given country invited to join NATO is largely dependent on this aspect of security-military relations.  If it's net contribution or utility does not exceed the net cost of its participation, it is reasonable to expect that an invitation to membership is problematic; in such cases, it is unlikely that it would even be included in the MAP process.  Invitation to membership indicates that a security utility is present for NATO.  Of course, the criteria for membership is larger than the question of security utility.  Since the MAP cycles have been completed and accession (formal invitation to membership) occurred, it is highly likely that Montenegro will become a NATO member at the Warsaw summit in early July 2016.

There's been anti-NATO protests since Dec 2nd, but nothing compared to what I was expecting.  I draw some conclusions from this:
1) Russia was encouraging the protests last fall more than I thought, perhaps as much as Djukanovic claimed
2) Jens Stoltzenberg says what he means. In fall, while NATO officials were visiting Montenegro it seemed that momentum for opposition to NATO and Djukanovic was building.  Protesters were demanding a referendum on NATO, elections, and end to corruption,including the end of Djukanovic.  After their visit,  NATO officials made many encouraging but conditional statements about Montenegro's readiness to join NATO.  I was of the opinion then, and continue to be, that NATO officials wanted to encourage Montenegro/Djukanovic, but also wanted to see progress in the area of rule of law, reduction in corruption, and new elections, and that an invitation to membership would not be extended, but promised if certain conditions were met.   Then, just prior to the December NATO meeting, Russia started to get really vocal about its opposition to Montenegro becoming a NATO member.   My sense is that THAT pushed Stoltzenberg into doing what he had not intended to do:  offer Montenegro an invitation of membership.  He said as much.  He said that Russia had no business interfering in NATO affairs, that its interference was having the opposite effect than Russia wanted.  So, I think that Montenegro's NATO membership invitation was not so much a statement of Montenegro's readiness, as it was a statement by NATO that it would not be bullied by Russia. So, now, what will NATO do with Montenegro?  Since Montenegro wasn't fully ready for NATO membership, and shouldn't perhaps have had an invitation extended to it recently, the accession process now will have to be used to complete the process of becoming ready that should have preceded the membership invitation.  This will make the accession process longer rather than shorter.  The timeline for EU membership is instructive. I will be paying close(er) attention to what Stoltzenberg says about the timeline for accession.

An optimistic backwards calculation of the schedule: Based on the last two accessions (Albania, Croatia 2008 --- but starting with Bulgaria's March 2003) schedules: - Goal: Achieving Montenegro's membership by December 15, 2016.
- Waiting time: One months (and two weeks) only for getting the last ratifiers (postal) letters to NATO HQ and doing the paper work there.
- Milestone: Last ratifier signs in the last week of October 2016.
- Get all 28 parliaments to ratify accession during March, April, May, June, July (5 months, dropping a month for summer recess), and during September and October 2016.
- No waiting time: The earliest ratification starts immediately after signing (as in March 2003 by Canada).
- Start: NATO hands out the accession protocol in March 2016 (as for Bulgaria etc in 2003), as foreign minister of [Montenegro] attends "a special session of the North Atlantic Council, NATO’s top decision-making body, at NATO Headquarters for the signing ceremony." http://www.nato.int/docu/update/2003/03-march/e0326b.htm Montenegro got its invitation four months earlier than Albania and Croatia, similar to the 2003/04 members, hence if NATO convenes a special session in the first quarter 2016, and Montenegro has not to wait until July's Warsaw summit for the signing, then the paperwork, schedules, summer recess and all parlamentarians of 28 countries could do it in about 7 months for ratification within 2016, if the French don't drag. It's two questions: (1) what is possible timeline for accession talks, culminating with signatures on the protocol and (2) what is possible timeline for ratification of this protocol in 28 legislative bodies. All other steps are presumably short. For the first question I have very strong bias telling me that
	- the decision is made and the talks will be technical. 
	- Nothing in current situation warrants any prolonged discussions. 
	- Nothing in "normal" (i .e. predictable) flow of things, including relations with Russia, troubles with elections, modest protests, etc., has almost no effect on these talks. All this was already factored in when decision was made to invite Montenegro. NATO will continue monitoring, but as long as things develop along foreseeable path, there will be no delays.
	- Accession to EU is totally different topic in this case. Albania and Croatia joined NATO in 2009, Croatia is EU member since 2013, Albania is still only official EU candidate. Montenegro EU accession target of 2021 is irrelevant.
	- All bets are off if during the talks some unpredictable stuff happens, coup, failure to agree regarding elections, or something like that.  So I am predicting that the talks will be technical and it will take about 2-4 months to finalize the protocol. Would say that I am 80-85% certain that the protocol will be signed by the end of March 2016. Looking from the other side - I think there's 15-20% probability that something bad happens influencing the "normal" accession procedure. Ratification timeline: assigning 80-85% probability that IF the protocol is signed by the end of March, it will pass all 28 parliaments by the end of 2016.  This question brings out the really fascinating value/nature of forecasting here - we may use same sources, same facts, yet we arrive on totally different conclusions, depending on how much weight we assign to certain pieces of information. Slovakia, Romania, Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Slovenia: invitation 11.2002, protocol signed 03.2003 (+4 months), last ratification 03.2004 (+12 months). In both cases accession talks were quite short, protocol signed in 3-4 months. Looks like the number of participants has not too much influence on this time, so Montenegro might be expected to reach the protocol on similar timeframe, maybe in 2 months, as they are really eager and alone in the process.  Ratification is a different issue. In 2003 it took 2 days (!) for Canadian government to ratify the protocols, Norwegian parliament used 2 weeks and French Senate 10 months [1]. Of course, ratification of 2004 enlargement was slightly different, as in 2004 spring several Eastern European countries were also admitted into EU, so some parliaments probably passed NATO/EU treaty amendments in package (don't know this, speculating).  In case of Estonia (as acceding country) the accession was scheduled to coincide with EU accession in 2004, so from technical point of view I guess it might have been quicker. Last 2 months, of the total 12 for ratification, was used by acceding countries. What I want to say here is that the 12 month for ratification is probably not very good number to base our forecast on. So purely technical case here is 2-4 months for talks/protocol and 6-10 months for ratifications. 8-14 months in total, counting form invitation. This elaboration does not account for possible delays in accession talks, don't know if there are any outstanding issues possibly delaying the protocol. In previous cases the talks have been technical. NATO Summit is held on 8-9 July 2016, 7 months and 1 week after the invitation. If we see very quick talks and protocol signed by the end of January, it may be signal that there is a pressure to finish the  process by the Summit. Wouldn't hold my breath for that. Elections in Montenegro are scheduled for 21 October 2016, almost 11 months after invitation. Basically the same time as with the last (Albania/Croatia) accession. If I were the king of Montenegro, I would probably do anything in my power to secure the NATO membership before elections. So given that (A) we have just one acceding country, (B) who seems to be in a hurry and (C) closing the case is technically possible before the end of 2016, I am optimistic.  [1] Full list with ratification dates is available here (in Estonian, Chrome translator works): http://vm.ee/et/ajalugu-eesti-liitumine-natoga

See citation below for good paper on the process of NATO Accession. (Yes, it was written by a group of college students. Still , they seem to have good citations and I think they have their facts correct.) Important parts are here: "The North Atlantic Council, as the principal political and decision making body of NATO, reviews the status of candidate members and upon consensus
decides which country to invite in order to begin accession talks with the members of the Alliance. However, this is the start of the accession process
which is highlighted by some major stages; the accession talks, the deposit of letters of intent to join NATO, the signing of accession protocols, the ratification
of accession protocols, the invitation from the Secretary General of NATO to the candidate countries to accede to the North Atlantic Treaty, the accession of the
invitees to the Treaty and the formal acquisition of NATO membership by the invitees.

"The first step for the accession of new members is the conduct of accession talks between the potential member and a NATO team. The accession
talks are a series of meetings between a team of NATO experts and the representatives of the individual invitees, aiming to “discuss and formally
confirm their interest, willingness and ability to meet the political, legal and military obligations and commitments of NATO membership.”57 The talks are
split into two sessions with each invitee; each session focuses on a special area of interest. The first session covers political, defense and military issues while the
second session covers the more technical aspects of the accession such as legal  issues and the contribution of the new member to the Alliance’s common
budget.58 The result of these talks is a timetable submitted by each invitee, which designates the completion of the reforms that have been discussed in the earlier talks with the NATO experts and that many of which may continue long after the accession of the respective country to NATO. "After the accession talks, the invitees have to send letters of intent to NATO, along with timetables which set the timeframe for the completion of the
agreed reforms. The letters of intent serve as a confirmation of the invitee’s interest, willingness and ability to join the Alliance and fulfill the obligations and
commitments that derive from a NATO membership. The letter of intent is submitted by the foreign ministers of the invited countries, and is addressed to
the Secretary General of NATO. "With the submission of the letters of intent, NATO will prepare accession protocols for each one of the invited countries.59 These protocols are in fact
amendments to the North Atlantic Treaty that will be incorporated to the Treaty once signed and ratified by the Alliance’s members. Once the accession protocols
are signed, they have to be ratified by NATO countries, according to their national procedures and requirements.60

"After the signing and ratification of the protocols, and their subsequent acceptance to the North Atlantic Treaty, the Government of the United States of
America is notified61 as is procedure62. The Secretary General of NATO then extends an invitation to the new countries to accede to the North Atlantic
Treaty.63   "Following their invitation from the Secretary General, the invited countries will have to ratify their accession protocols according to their national
procedures, and then to deposit their ratified accession instruments to the Government of the United States of America. Upon depositing their accession
instruments to the Government of the USA, the invited members formally become full members of the Alliance." http://thessismun.org/2014/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/NAC-A.pdf Montenegro is at the first step of a long series of requirements. Given the current controversy (artificially inflated though it may be), it's hard to see how they get through this process in a year.

Two countries invited April 2008, ascended April 2009. I have no idea why previous three ascensions occurred in March/April, but I'm going to guess there is a target of March 2017 for Montenegro becoming a member. Unlikely within 2016. Also weighing against Montenegro, among other things ,this requires US Senate approval. While I'm sure the US Senate will support eventually, Congressional disfunction is real.

The last group of countries to be accepted into NATO (Albania, Croatia) were invited to start accession talks in 3-4 April 2008 and were accepted as NATO members on 1 April 2009. That's a year and 3 days. The group before that (Slovakia, Romania, Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Slovenia) were accepted as members on 29 March 2004 and were invited to join on 21-22 November 2002. That's 16 months. The group before that (Hungary, Poland, Czech Republic) was invited on 8-9 July, 1997 and were accepted on 12 March 1999. That's 20 months. These are the only examples in the post-Cold War era. The timeline above suggests a base rate of about 33%. However, Montenegro has to demonstrate more progress on reforms. While a December 2016 date is a good possibility (giving Montenegro about a year), I am starting out with a cautious "No" forecast. "The proposed text has been approved at (NATO) ambassador level," one source said Monday, asking not to be named. "After that, it would take at most a year and a half for Montenegro to become a member state," the source added."
Due to the regional tensions, I do not consider Montenegro being able to secure NATO membership.
